Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Studies of Parton Distributions using Kaons at Jefferson Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is well known that protons and neutrons are made from constituents, called quarks and gluons, which give substructure to these particles. The goal of this project is to make measurements of the spatial distributions and the momenta of the quarks that provide a three-dimensional map of quarks in the nuclear medium. This knowledge provides the basis of our understanding of nuclear matter in terms of the dynamics of their internal constituents. Using this information, theoretical models show how the constituent parts of the proton and neutron can be used to build up its fundamental intrinsic properties, i.e. its overall size, or radius, and quantum mechanical spin.

This project engages the PI and Duquesne University's undergraduate students in research aiming to study the strange sea using semi-inclusive production of Kaons with CLAS12 at Jefferson Lab. Physics analysis of 6 GeV Kaon data from eg2 experiment and software development projects for 12 GeV experiments will be performed at Duquesne University, while hardware and detector tests will be carried out at Jefferson Lab. The PI is leading the calibrations of a hybrid Ring Imaging CHerenkov (RICH) detector which is currently under construction. This detector will be used for hadron identification in the momentum range of 3 to 8 GeV/c. Undergraduates play an integral part in this project, which provides them with opportunities to further their training and education outside of the classroom. This will include: gaining experience in the design, assembly, and testing of modern particle Physics detectors, high tech fast electronics, and scientific data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Measurements with identified strange hadrons can provide important information on several topics in hadronic physics: the nucleon tomography and quark orbital momentum, accessible through the study of the Generalized Parton Distributio (GPDs) and the Transverse Momentum dependent parton Distribution functions (TMDs), the quark hadronization in the nuclear medium, the hadron spectroscopy, the search for exotic mesons and the topic of this proposal: the parton distributions and the fragmentation functions. This project engaged the PI and Duquesne undergraduate students in research aiming to study the partonic distributions using semi-inclusive production of Kaons in CLAS12 in Hall-B at Jefferson Lab. Data taking and Physics analysis for unpolarized and polarized deuterium and hydrogen targets are part of this project. In addition, the PI lead the efforts in software development, characterization, reconstruction and calibrations of a  hybrid Ring Imaging Cherenkov detector (RICH) and is applying her group?s manpower and gained expertise to the building and testing of second RICH detector that will be installed head on to the first one. Students participated in hardware and electronics projects that took place at Jefferson Lab or at INFN laboratories and many software development and data analysis projects that were performed locally at Duquesne. Several instrumentation peer reviewed papers and presentations in national and international conferences by the PI and her students resulted from this work. Data collection on unpolarized hydrogen and deuterium targets is well advanced and a polarized target is under construction for the second part of the measurements.  

Knowledge of Parton Distribution Functions (PDFs) represents the basis of our understanding of hadronic matter in terms of its fundamental degrees of freedom. The results of this research project will lead to critical improvements in several areas of spin physics including in the strangeness sector. The ensuing dramatic improvement in the knowledge of fragmentation functions will be an important ingredient in the global analysis of the nucleon structure from semi-inclusive Deep-Inelastic-Scattering and pp collision data. Thus contributing in a unique way to the challenge of understanding how partons build up all intrinsic properties of the nucleon, in particular how they share the nucleon spin. This is one of the main goals of the upgraded 12 GeV CEBAF accelerator at JLab and future Ion Collider (EIC). Final results will be disseminated in peer-reviewed scientific journals and considerable coverage in more broad-based literature, such as dailies and periodicals at an international level. The results will serve as reference input to other experiments in Nuclear and high energy Physics.

Besides advancing fundamental science, education of students was a central component of this proposed project. We had outstanding opportunities to contribute to this goal as well as a very strong record of accomplishment in this area. We were committed to providing meaningful and useful research experiences to our students. Duquesne undergraduates play an important role in this project, which provided them with opportunities to further their training and education outside the classroom. This included; gaining experience in the design, high tech fast electronics and scientific data analysis. As with previous students who worked with the PI, these students had the chance to present their work to the university community and at the American Physical Society?s Division of Nuclear Physics (APS/DNP) meetings. 35% of the undergraduate students in the physics department at Duquesne are female and the PI is playing a role model in her research, she particularly encouraging the engagements of these students in STEM-related fields. In addition, three African American students were supported by this grant and the PI provided them with the best training and guidance to achieve their dream of becoming future Nuclear Physicists.
